column13: *this was a hard call. They assign germs to "phylogroups" though not based on phylogenetics. Within each phylogroup, they do a dendrogram based on "Ward's minimum-variance method" but this is for general clustering, and the results don't seem to be interpreted as phylogenetic trees (just "similarity"). Also, fun fact: "community-dwelling humans" does not mean humans who aren't hermits, as I first suspected, but rather humans who aren't patients with an identified feature (in this case, urinary tract infections).
